def.p: Any substance that causes your immune system to produce antibodies against it.
The degree to which an agent has specific destructive action on certain cells.
A change in a cell causing an increase in morphological or chemical heterogeneity.
Changing a cell type with limited lifespan in vitro into a cell type with unlimited capacity to proliferate; sometimes achieved by animal cells in vitro or by tumor cells.
Cell growth outside the body, in glass, as in a test tube.
Cell growth in a living organism.
A buffered selection of components in which an organism naturally lives or grows.
A single layer of adherent cells on substratum.
The process of passing or maintaining cells through a series of hosts or cultures.
A culture initiated from an explant of cells, tissues, or organs in media conducive to their growth.
Use of the enzyme trypsin to remove adherence proteins from a cell surface.
